coredata.dc:title: Perturbation theory and the radial distribution function of fluids with nonspherical potentials
coredata.dc:creator: Smith, William R.
Madden, William G.
Fitts, Donald D.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A perturbation expansion for the radial distribution function of fluids with nonspherical pair potentials is discussed. Numerical calculations are presented for dipolar hard-sphere and quadrupolar hard-sphere fluids. Agreement with the computer simulation results is excellent, even at high dipole and quadrupole moments.

Introduction Perturbation theory is now well established as a simple and accurate means of calculating the thermo- dynamic propertics and radial distribution functions of fluids whose molecules interact via spherically symmetric pair potentials [1,21. Although some at- tempts have been made to extend these theories to consider fluids whose molecules are not spherically symmetric [3 12], the accuracy of the calculations is usually limited to small ariisotropy, especially in the calculations of pair distribution functions. Most of these perturbation theories expand the properties of the fluid about those of a reference fluid svhose molecules have spherically symmetric pair po- tentials. This course is usually followed for ease of computation and because the properties of the chosen reference systems are often well known. Some authors [6,7,13] have questioned the validity of the principle of using a spherically symmetric refer- ence fluid to calculate the properties of nonspherical molecular fluids. However, in this paper, we show that such a scheme may be used provided the reference system is appropriately chosen. In this note, we pre- sent a new derivation of a form of expansion consid- ered previously by others [11,12,16] and apply it to some recently obtained computer simulation results for fluids of hard spheres with imbedded point dipoles or quadrupoles [14]. Our calculated pair distribution functions show excellent agreement with these exact results, even at large dipole and quadrupole moments. 2.
